case_vignette: A 23-year-old G1P0 with a history of epilepsy gives birth to a male infant at 33 weeks gestation. The mother had no prenatal care and took no prenatal vitamins. The infant appears somnolent and is not crying. The child’s temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 30/min. On physical examination in the delivery room, the child has a membranous pouch extruding over the thoracolumbar spine. His lower extremities are flaccid. A brain MRI is shown in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby seems very sleepy and isn't crying.
How old is your baby?
He was just born.
Is your baby eating and breastfeeding well?
He appears somnolent, which makes it seem like he's not very alert or active right now.
Is your baby having any trouble breathing or any change in skin color?
His breathing rate is 30 per minute, which hasn't been mentioned as problematic, and nothing has been said about a change in skin color.
Does your baby have a history of any medical conditions or was there anything abnormal during the pregnancy?
I have a history of epilepsy, but there was no prenatal care, and I didn't take any prenatal vitamins.
Has your baby been given any medications or been exposed to any substances during your pregnancy?
No, there is no mention of medications or substance exposure during the pregnancy.
**Final Diagnosis:** Neonatal Hypoglycemia

I'm feeling really sleepy and I'm not crying like you would expect a baby to.
How old are you?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I just gave birth to a baby who seems very sleepy and is not crying.
Congratulations on the birth! Did you have a full-term pregnancy?
No, the baby was born at 33 weeks, so it was a premature birth.
Has the baby been having any trouble breathing or any episodes of apnea?
No, the baby's breathing rate is at 30 per minute, so there's no trouble breathing mentioned.
Is the baby's skin color normal, or does it appear bluish?
The baby's skin color isn't mentioned, so it seems normal as there's no mention of a bluish color.
Does the baby have any congenital medical conditions or birth defects that you're aware of?
Yes, the baby has a pouch-like thing over the back where the spine is, and also the baby's lower limbs are very weak.
I see, has the baby been given any medications or treatments since birth?
No, there's no mention of any medications or treatments given to the baby since birth.
Does anyone in the family have a history of genetic disorders or birth defects?
I have epilepsy, but there's no mention of any other family history of genetic disorders or birth defects.
**Final Diagnosis:** Myelomeningocele (Spina Bifida)
